items.title: Unhelpful TypeError exception in sampling
items.body:
#### Summary:

I try to fit a model and get ignored TypeError exceptions and messages from "<cppobj>._set_stanargs_from_dict.  The error message doesn't tell me where the problem is. 

#### Description:
I'm not sure if the bug is that this error happens at all or if it's just an unhelpful error message.


#### Reproducible Steps:
I discovered the issue trying to fit the attached model (heaps_poisson_seasonality.stan) with pystan 0.19.1.1  The model was working fine until I went to add conditional operators on line 95 so the stan program can work even if no seasonality data is passed in.  I'll also provide data (data.pickle) and a python script for fitting the model (test.py).

The files are in reproduce.zip
[reproduce.zip](https://github.com/stan-dev/pystan/files/5079795/reproduce.zip)




#### Current Output:
```
TypeError: an integer is required
Exception ignored in: 'stanfit4heaps_poisson_seasonality_67eb88e318d6ffbb733000448e59f687_9047264962651855902._set_stanargs_from_dict'
TypeError: an integer is required
TypeError: an integer is required
Exception ignored in: 'stanfit4heaps_poisson_seasonality_67eb88e318d6ffbb733000448e59f687_9047264962651855902._set_stanargs_from_dict'
TypeError: an integer is required
TypeError: an integer is required
Exception ignored in: 'stanfit4heaps_poisson_seasonality_67eb88e318d6ffbb733000448e59f687_9047264962651855902._set_stanargs_from_dict'
TypeError: an integer is required
TypeError: an integer is required
Exception ignored in: 'stanfit4heaps_poisson_seasonality_67eb88e318d6ffbb733000448e59f687_9047264962651855902._set_stanargs_from_dict'
TypeError: an integer is required

```


#### Expected Output:
I'd like the model to fit or an error message telling me what is wrong.


#### PyStan Version:
2.19.1.1

#### Python Version:
3.7.7

#### Operating System:
CentOS 7

items.title: distutils.errors.CompileError: command ‘gcc’ failed with exit status 1
items.body:
#### Summary:
I am new to pystan, and I tried compiling a simple model, but I am getting a gcc failed status

#### Description:
I am running this in a Python 3 environment. 

#### Reproducible Steps:
schools_code = """
data {
    int<lower=0> J; // number of schools
    real y[J]; // estimated treatment effects
    real<lower=0> sigma[J]; // s.e. of effect estimates
}
parameters {
    real mu;
    real<lower=0> tau;
    real eta[J];
}
transformed parameters {
    real theta[J];
    for (j in 1:J)
        theta[j] = mu + tau * eta[j];
}
model {
    eta ~ normal(0, 1);
    y ~ normal(theta, sigma);
}
"""

schools_dat = {'J': 8,
               'y': [28,  8, -3,  7, -1,  1, 18, 12],
               'sigma': [15, 10, 16, 11,  9, 11, 10, 18]}

sm = pystan.StanModel(model_code=schools_code)
fit = sm.sampling(data=schools_dat, iter=1000, chains=4)

print(fit)

eta = fit.extract(permuted=True)['eta']
np.mean(eta, axis=0)

# if matplotlib is installed (optional, not required), a visual summary and
# traceplot are available
fit.plot()
plt.show()

items.title: Reproducibility on different machines
items.body:
#### Summary:
Using the seed and init functionality, I get reproducible results on one computer. However, I get a different set of results on another computer for the same exact inputs. The results are reproducible within multiple runs on the same computer, but they differ on different computers.


#### Description:
For the "optimizing" and "sampling" functions of PyStan, I cannot create reproducible results on different computers. I am sure to set both the init and the seed variables as inputs. On one computer with multiple runs, I always get the same outputs. On the other computer I am using, I also get the same outputs for every run, but it is a different set of outputs than I get from the 1st computer. The computers are consistent with themselves, but not consistent with each other.

A strange thing is that for the "vb" functions of PyStan, I get the same outputs across all computers.

Note: for all 3 functions, I'm using the same cached model. 

Can you help me understand why this is happening? I'd like to be able to reproduce my outputs across all computers I work on. 

#### PyStan Version: 2.19.1.1 - CVODES branch

#### Python Version: 3.7.6 on one computer, 3.7.3 on the other 

#### Operating System: One is Linux, the other is Windows.

Difficulty installing cvodes version of pystan.


#### Description:
I tried to follow the documentation using this command: 
pip install https://github.com/stan-dev/pystan/archive/v2.18.0.0-cvodes.tar.gz
It didn't work (I include my output below).

I also tried using the solution proposed at this issue #650 but it failed on the "git checkout sundials_update" step saying:
error: pathspec 'sundials_update' did not match any file(s) known to git
Note: this has worked for me in the past in other environments. It seems that now the "sundials_update" file is now missing.


#### Reproducible Steps:
command line: conda install libpython m2w64-toolchain -c msys2

items.title: Updating outdated model and addressing 'variable does not exist' error
Hierarchical Bayesian modeling
items.body:
#### Summary:
Hi to all!
I am implementing a bayesian model for feature selection using spike and slab prior in an advanced way with respect to my previous issue. I found Stan really functional for my goals.

The idea was a model like this:

```
y ~ Bernoulli(p_{i})
p_{i} ~function(x_i * beta)

with 
beta_j | lambda_j ~ Normal(0,lambda_j)
lambda_j | c_j , gamma_j  ~ equals(gamma_j ,0)*c1+equals(gamma_j ,1)*c2

gamma_j | w_j ~ Bernoulli(w_j)
```
My model code is the following;

```

code = """                                                                                           
data {                                                                                               
  int N; //the number of training observations                                                       
  int N2; //the number of test observations                                                          
  int K; //the number of features                                                                    
  int y[N]; //the response                                                                           
  matrix[N,K] X; //the model matrix                                                                  
  matrix[N2,K] new_X; //the matrix for the predicted values  
  real c1;
  real c2;
  real theta;
}                                                                                                    
parameters {                                                                                         
  real alpha;
  
  vector[K] beta; //the regression parameters     
  int g[K];

}                                                                                                    
transformed parameters {                                                                             
  vector[N] linpred;
  linpred = alpha+X*beta; 

}                                                                                                    
model {                                                                                              
  alpha ~ normal(0.0,10.0);                          


  for(j in 1:K) {                                                                                     
    

    g[j]~ bernoulli(theta);
    beta[j] ~ normal(0,equals(g[j],0)*c1+equals(g[j],1)*c2);

    
    }
    
    
  y ~ bernoulli_logit(linpred);                                                                      
}                                                                                                    
generated quantities {                                                                               
  vector[N2] y_pred;  
  vector[N2] prob_pred;
  y_pred = alpha+new_X*beta; //the y values predicted by the model              
  for (n in 1:N2) {
  prob_pred[n]=1/(1+exp(-y_pred[n]));
    }
}                                                                                                    
""" 

```
The error I bumped into is:
```
ValueError: Failed to parse Stan model 'anon_model_f2a73b8b7c7d49dc2df206c9d2c8fae2'. Error message:
SYNTAX ERROR, MESSAGE(S) FROM PARSER:
Parameters or transformed parameters cannot be integer or integer array;  found int variable declaration, name=g
 error in 'unknown file name' at line 17, column 10

```
The rest of the code is:

```
data = {                                                                                             
    'N': 250,                                                                                        
    'N2': 19750,                                                                                     
    'K': 300,                                                                                        
    'y': target,                                                                                     
    'X': train,                                                                                      
    'new_X': test,     
    'c1': c1,
    'c2': c2,
    'theta': 0.5
} 
sm = pystan.StanModel(model_code=code,verbose=True) 

```

It seems that I cannot sample from a Bernoulli

PyStan Version: pystan==2.19.1.1
Python Version: 3.7
Operating System: Windows 10

Do you have any suggestion to correct my model thus not causing the error? Which is my mistake in the model code?

items.title: Byte string for vb filename?
items.body:
#### Summary:
Right now, `vb` returns a byte string for the file of parameters.
Specifically, if one runs a stan program like below

```python
fit = sm.vb(data=dat, iter=10000)
```

the `fit['args']['sample_file']` returns a byte string.

This is pretty awkward from a users perspective, since the user needs to manually convert it into a real string like as follows

```python
''.join(list(map(chr, fit['args']['sample_file'])))
```

I'm not familiar with the design decisions behind this - but it would be very advantageous to return a string by default rather than a byte string. 

This is run using pystan version 2.19.1.1

items.title: summary() method of stanfit4model returns jumbled per-chain summaries
items.body:
#### Summary:
When calling the summary() method on a stanfit object, the per-chain summaries in the 'c_summary' array are incorrect.


#### Description:
I'm comparing the 'c_summary' array to what would be expected based on [this documentation](https://pystan.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#pystan.StanFit4model.summary). The array appears to have the correct dimension, but the statistics in it are jumbled and out of order. The statistics in the 'summary' array appear correct, however.


#### Reproducible Steps:
```
import pystan

print("Pystan version {}".format(pystan.__version__))

model = """
parameters {
    real x;
    real<lower=0> y;
    real<lower=0,upper=1> z;
}
model {
    x ~ normal(0,1);
    y ~ exponential(1);
    z ~ uniform(0,1);
}
"""
fit = pystan.stan(model_code=model, iter=2000, warmup=1000, chains=4)
summary = fit.summary(['x','y','z'])

# Works as expected
print("Overall Summary")
print(summary['summary'].shape)
print(summary['summary_rownames'])
print(summary['summary_colnames'])
print(summary['summary'])

#Doesn't work as expected
print("\nPer-chain Summaries")
print(summary['c_summary'].shape)
for c in range(4):
    print("Chain {}:".format(c))
    print(summary['c_summary_rownames'])
    print(summary['c_summary_colnames'])
    print(summary['c_summary'][:,:,c])
```

items.title: PyStan does not obey print() command
Function to separate divergent and non-divergent transitions
items.body:
@betanalpha has a function `partition_div` [here](https://github.com/betanalpha/knitr_case_studies/blob/master/gaussian_processes/gp_part3/stan_utility.R). Pasted below:

```R
# Returns parameter arrays separated into divergent and non-divergent transitions
partition_div <- function(fit) {
  nom_params <- extract(fit, permuted=FALSE)
  n_chains <- dim(nom_params)[2]
  params <- as.data.frame(do.call(rbind, lapply(1:n_chains, function(n) nom_params[,n,])))

  sampler_params <- get_sampler_params(fit, inc_warmup=FALSE)
  divergent <- do.call(rbind, sampler_params)[,'divergent__']
  params$divergent <- divergent

  div_params <- params[params$divergent == 1,]
  nondiv_params <- params[params$divergent == 0,]

  return(list(div_params, nondiv_params))
}
```
I cannot find it in PyStan.
Is it implemented anywhere?


#### PyStan Version: 2.19.0.0

items.title: conda-forge PyStan is 2.17.1.0 while Anaconda Cloud has 2.19.0.0
items.body:
#### Summary:
An outdated version of PyStan is on conda-forge, while the Anaconda default channel has the latest.  Because conda-forge recommends (and, for some packages, requires) that it live at higher priority than the default channel many users will not be able to access the Anaconda default.

#### Description:
See above.  This problem is fixable in several ways:

* By uploading the latest PyStan to conda-forge as well as Anaconda Cloud.  

* By removing PyStan from conda-forge.  Now users will default to the Anaconda Cloud installation even when following the approved procedure for adding the conda-forge channel to their conda installation.  Note that this is the recommended procedure from conda-forge for packages that appear in the Anaconda defaults channel as well.

items.title: CompileError: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1 mac OS
How are mean, std and quantiles calculated?
items.body:
Hi,

I was wondering how the statistics in summary are calculated.
There is very nice documentation on MCSE, n_eff, Rhat and E-BFMI, but I cannot find any on means and standard deviations.

I found a reference to the code in a comment [here](https://github.com/stan-dev/pystan/issues/396#issuecomment-343447596).
Although I have tried I cannot follow the code or find where the actual calculation occurs.

If I have 4 chains and 1000 samples is n_eff then used to extract the amount of independent samples from which the mean is calculated?
And if the mean is calculated for each chain is it then combined  mu=sqrt{mu_1 + mu_2 + mu_3 + mu_4}? Or does the between chain variance also have some influence here?
If n_eff=500 I assume every second sample is used. But what about n_eff>1000?

Thanks in advance!

items.title: appveyor account -> pystan
items.body: There's a pystan organization account on appveyor. I believe riddell-stan and ahartikainen are both owners of it. It should be running the tests and (eventually) building wheels.

items.title: Installing Pystan on Android
items.body:
#### Summary:

I've seen a couple of posts in which it seems as if installing `pystan` on Android (with Termux and `clang` is possible. I was wondering if there was a guide to do so, as I've been running into an error when attempting to install `pystan`.

#### Reproducible Steps:

Here's the command I've been using:
```
$ LDFLAGS=" -lm -lcompiler_rt" pip install -U pystan
```

#### Current Output:

I've been getting this error, primarily:
```
Command "/data/data/com.termux/files/usr/bin/python -u -c "import setuptools, tokenize;__file__='/data/data/com.termux/files/usr/tmp/pip-install-ry7jkr43/pystan/setup.py';f=getattr(tokenize, 'open', open)(__file__);code=f.read().replace('\r\n', '\n');f.close();exec(compile(code, __file__, 'exec'))" install --record /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/tmp/pip-record-fs3xjrpt/install-record.txt --single-version-externally-managed --compile" failed with error code 1 in /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/tmp/pip-install-ry7jkr43/py
```

Any help would be greatly appreciated, thanks!

items.body:
#### Summary:
I am new to pystan. I am having difficulty creating a StanModel. 


#### Description:
I am using mingw64 with gcc 8.1.0. Before, when I tried to run the example in the pystan installation guide for windows, it would say no MSVC compiler 1916. I edited the file cygwinccompiler.py, adding 

elif msc_ver == '1916':
            return ['vcruntime140']

I have a distutils.cfg file that says

[build]
compiler=mingw32

[build_ext]
compiler=mingw32

When I run the example now, I get:

command 'C:\\Program Files\\mingw-w64\\x86_64-8.1.0-posix-seh-rt_v6-rev0\\mingw64\\bin\\gcc.exe' failed with exit status 1

What can I do? Thank you in advance.

#### PyStan Version: 2.18.1.0

#### Python Version: 3.6.8

items.title: Fix Windows build for 2.19
items.body: Windows build fails on appveyor because of extremely long filepaths (in boost). In httpstan we solve this by removing these files from the repository. This strategy doesn't work with PyStan 2 because we use git submodules.

items.title: Update related projects
items.body:
I think we should update our Readme(+docs) for the related projects.

I gathered some of the projects I follow:

Plotting / data management

ArviZ https://github.com/arviz-devs/arviz

Modelling interfaces

Prophet https://github.com/facebook/prophet
BAMBI https://github.com/bambinos/bambi

Jupyter Tools

StanMagic https://github.com/Arvinds-ds/stanmagic
JupyterStan https://github.com/janfreyberg/jupyterstan

If there is some missing, please add a comment.

Also maybe we should add more information about PyStan3(Stan3)?

#### Summary:
Compilation error on Pystan 2.18.1.0

#### Description:
I am running Pystan on a Linux environment. I am running Python 3.5.2 and gcc 4.4.7. When trying to run the Eight Schools example, I get the output below.
It should be noted that I am able to run this on my laptop (Win10) and this occurred after changing to my universities servers. I do not have permission to install anything on the servers and would therefore like an educated guess before I go running to the administrator. 
I have check my Cython version, it is newer than 0.22. (Issue [219](https://github.com/stan-dev/pystan/issues/219) )
There is no error telling me to install a development version of Python. (Issue [245](https://github.com/stan-dev/pystan/issues/245))
Issue [550](https://github.com/stan-dev/pystan/issues/550) seems to be IOS based, is I am not mistaken.
Several possible solution were found in issue [470](https://github.com/stan-dev/pystan/issues/470), still open. I do not have build-essential installed, this might be a solution.

items.title: Setup error on python 3.7 with cython 0.29.6 (with proposed workaround)
items.body:
#### Summary:
Compilation error when installing latest pystan release.

#### Description:
On python 3.6.8 with cython 0.29.6, installation from sdist works.
On python 3.7.2 with cython 0.29.6, installation from sdist does not work. When I download the source tarball from pypi and remove some cython generated files, I can build the wheel manually (see "proposed workaround").

#### Reproducible Steps:
`pip install --no-binary pystan --force-reinstall pystan` from a 3.7 venv.

#### Proposed workaround
Do not distribute cython generated files `_api.cpp`, `_chains.cpp` and `_misc.cpp` : make cython a required dep, and use it during pip build to recompile them instead.

#### Current Output:
```
[many errors like the following one]
    pystan/_misc.cpp:18836:13: error: 'PyThreadState' {aka 'struct _ts'} has no member named 'exc_traceback'; did you mean 'curexc_traceback'?
         tstate->exc_traceback = *tb;
                 ^~~~~~~~~~~~~
                 curexc_traceback
```

#### Expected Output:
```
  Running setup.py install for pystan ... done
Successfully installed Cython-0.29.6 numpy-1.16.2 pystan-2.18.1.0
```

#### PyStan Version:
`2.18.1.0`

#### Python Version:
`3.7.2`

#### Operating System:
`Gentoo`

items.title: BUGFIX: pystan build on Windows platform using mingw64 gcc
items.body: #### Summary: Hi, the setup.py script needs a small fix in order to build pystan on Windows 7 x64 platform. Extension("pystan._misc", ["pystan/_misc.pyx"], language='c++', extra_compile_args=extra_compile_args) #### Description: The misc.pyx extension raised an error like below: D:/msys64/mingw64/include/c++/8.3.0/cmath:1121:11: error: '::hypot' has not been declared using ::hypot; ^~~~~ Reason is quite obvious, setup.py doesn't pass *extra_compile_args* to this extension building block, which contains intented flags for MingW64 platform. #### Reproducible Steps: 1. install msys2 64bit and fetch all latest package updates using pacman. 1. install *mingw-w64-x86_64-toolchain* via pacman. 1. add msys2 mingw64 bin path to *PATH* environment variable, which in my case is D:\msys64\mingw64\bin 1. alternatively, the first three steps above could be done via following the official documentation page, from the conda environment. 1. install pystan via pip command line. #### Current Output: compile options: '-D__MSVCRT_VERSION__=0x1914 -ID:\pyvenv\crushburn\include -IC: \Program Files\Python37\include -IC:\Program Files\Python37\include -c' gcc -g -DDEBUG -DMS_WIN64 -O0 -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -D__MSVCRT_VERSION__=0x1 914 -ID:\pyvenv\crushburn\include -IC:\Program Files\Python37\include -IC:\Progr am Files\Python37\include -c pystan/_misc.cpp -o build\temp.win-amd64-3.7\Releas e\pystan\_misc.o cc1plus.exe: warning: command line option '-Wstrict-prototypes' is valid for C/O bjC but not for C++ In file included from D:/msys64/mingw64/include/c++/8.3.0/math.h:36, from C:\Program Files\Python37\include/pyport.h:191, from C:\Program Files\Python37\include/Python.h:53, from pystan/_misc.cpp:17: D:/msys64/mingw64/include/c++/8.3.0/cmath:1121:11: error: '::hypot' has not been declared using ::hypot; ^~~~~ error: Command "gcc -g -DDEBUG -DMS_WIN64 -O0 -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -D__MSVC RT_VERSION__=0x1914 -ID:\pyvenv\crushburn\include -IC:\Program Files\Python37\in clude -IC:\Program Files\Python37\include -c pystan/_misc.cpp -o build\temp.win- amd64-3.7\Release\pystan\_misc.o" failed with exit status 1 #### Expected Output: compile options: '-D__MSVCRT_VERSION__=0x1914 -ID:\pyvenv\crushburn\include -IC: \Program Files\Python37\include -IC:\Program Files\Python37\include -c' extra options: '-Os -ftemplate-depth-256 -Wno-unused-function -Wno-uninitialized -std=c++11 -D_hypot=hypot -pthread -fexceptions' gcc -g -DDEBUG -DMS_WIN64 -O0 -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -D__MSVCRT_VERSION__=0x1 914 -ID:\pyvenv\crushburn\include -IC:\Program Files\Python37\include -IC:\Progr am Files\Python37\include -c pystan/_misc.cpp -o build\temp.win-amd64-3.7\Releas e\pystan\_misc.o -Os -ftemplate-depth-256 -Wno-unused-function -Wno-uninitialize d -std=c++11 -D_hypot=hypot -pthread -fexceptions cc1plus.exe: warning: command line option '-Wstrict-prototypes' is valid for C/O bjC but not for C++ g++ -g -shared build\temp.win-amd64-3.7\Release\pystan\_misc.o -LD:\pyvenv\crush burn\libs -LC:\Program Files\Python37\libs -LC:\Program Files\Python37 -LD:\pyve nv\crushburn\PCbuild\amd64 -lpython37 -o build\lib.win-amd64-3.7\pystan\_misc.cp 37-win_amd64.pyd #### PyStan Version: * 2.18.1.0 #### Python Version: * 3.7.0 (official build) #### Operating System: * MSYS_NT-6.1 SQSZ-D0741 2.11.2(0.329/5/3) 2018-11-26 09:22 x86_64 Msys * Windows 7 x64

items.title: Can't load fits generated from different linux distributions
items.body:
#### Summary:
I run pystan on two machines. One machine runs Ubuntu 16.04 and the other machine runs Centos 7.3

I can successfully run and save models and fits on each machine.

However, on the Ubuntu machine I can only load the model and fit that were compiled and run on the Ubuntu machine. That is, my Ubuntu machine will not load the fit that was created by the Centos machine.

The converse is also true: Centos will load the model and fit produced on Centos, but it will not load the model and fit from Ubuntu.

#### Example:

On both machines I run the 8 schools example from the pystan readthedocs page.

```py
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import pickle
import pystan
import platform

schools_code = """
data {
    int<lower=0> J; // number of schools
    vector[J] y; // estimated treatment effects
    vector<lower=0>[J] sigma; // s.e. of effect estimates
}
parameters {
    real mu;
    real<lower=0> tau;
    vector[J] eta;
}
transformed parameters {
    vector[J] theta;
    theta = mu + tau * eta;
}
model {
    eta ~ normal(0, 1);
    y ~ normal(theta, sigma);
}
"""

schools_dat = {'J': 8,
               'y': [28,  8, -3,  7, -1,  1, 18, 12],
               'sigma': [15, 10, 16, 11,  9, 11, 10, 18]}

sm = pystan.StanModel(model_code=schools_code)
fit = sm.sampling(data=schools_dat, iter=1000, chains=4)

with open('{}_model.pkl'.format(platform.dist()[0]), "wb") as f:
	pickle.dump(sm, f, protocol=-1)

with open('{}_fit.pkl'.format(platform.dist()[0]), "wb") as f:
	pickle.dump(fit, f, protocol=-1)
```

This produces the files  ```Ubuntu_fit.pkl```, ```Ubuntu_model.pkl```, ```centos_fit.pkl``` and ```centos_model.pkl```. I copy over the pickle files so that both machines have all the files. Next I run the following on both machines:

```py
#! /usr/bin/env python3

import pickle
import platform

def try_load(file):
    try:
        with open(file, "rb") as f:
            _ = pickle.load(f)
        print("\n{} loaded {}\n".format(platform.dist()[0], file))
    except:
        print("\n{} couldn't load {}\n".format(platform.dist()[0], file))

files = ["Ubuntu_model.pkl", "Ubuntu_fit.pkl", "centos_model.pkl", "centos_fit.pkl"]

for file in files:
    try_load(file)
```

Running the above code on the centos machine I get:

```sh
user@centos$ ./load_test.py
WARNING:pystan:No module named 'stanfit4anon_model_19a09b474d1901f191444eaf8a6b8ce2_447963108405636165'
WARNING:pystan:Something went wrong while unpickling the StanModel. Consider recompiling.
centos loaded Ubuntu_model.pkl
centos couldn't load Ubuntu_fit.pkl
centos loaded centos_model.pkl
centos loaded centos_fit.pkl
```

And running the load code on my ubuntu machine I get

```sh
user@ubuntu$ ./load_test.py
Ubuntu loaded Ubuntu_model.pkl
Ubuntu loaded Ubuntu_fit.pkl
WARNING:pystan:No module named 'stanfit4anon_model_19a09b474d1901f191444eaf8a6b8ce2_3889597361207356136'
WARNING:pystan:Something went wrong while unpickling the StanModel. Consider recompiling.
Ubuntu loaded centos_model.pkl
Ubuntu couldn't load centos_fit.pkl
```

#### Versions:

On both OS's I am using pystan version 2.18.1.0 and numpy version 1.16.1.

On the Centos machine I have Cython version 0.29.4 and Ubuntu I have Cython version 0.29.5.

On the Centos machine I run Python 3.6.1 and on Ubuntu I run Python 3.5.2 (though I didn't think this should cause an issue)

#### Python versions:

I don't have sudo rights on either machine, so I haven't aligned python versions. I also didn't think this should be a problem, but if you do I can try building python from source on one of the machines to make sure both are running the same version.

Hi,
I am aware this is a vague question and am only looking for ideas and suggestions.

I am using NUTS for sampling spherical harmonics (SH). I am currently playing around with SH-degree 20-30, resulting in 500-1000 model parameters.
I use default settings: 4 chains with 1000 warm-up and 1000 post warm-up iterations, 10 tree-depth (never been necessary to increase). Always get Rhat=1.

Here's the question:

Do any of you have any suggestions as to why it can vary so much?

Thanks in advance
Michael

items.title: size of Effective Sample Size
items.body:
#### Summary:
Hi,
I am using pyStan with default settings.
A small section of the fit is shown below:

>> Inference for Stan model: None_c4ed8c57c14f2eabbd4599b428df4a4c.
>> 4 chains, each with iter=2000; warmup=1000; thin=1; 
>> post-warmup draws per chain=1000, total post-warmup draws=4000.

>>    mean     se_mean      sd    2.5%     25%     50%     75%   97.5%   n_eff   Rhat
>> m[1]  -5.2e4  9.8e-5 7.7e-3 -5.2e4 -5.2e4 -5.2e4 -5.2e4 -5.2e4   6190    1.0
>> m[2]  3138.7  1.0e-4 8.7e-3 3138.7 3138.7 3138.7 3138.7 3138.7   7062    1.0
>> m[3]  680.29  1.1e-4 8.8e-3 680.28 680.29 680.29  680.3 680.31   6155    1.0

If I am understanding it correctly, probably not, Then each chain provide 1000 samples giving a total of 4000 samples. How is it then possible to end up with an effective sample size larger than 4000?

If I have read correctly it is calculated as
>> n_eff = N/(1+2*sum(corr(lag)))

Thanks in advance
Michael

items.title: pystan does not return a dictionary
model.py optimizing function raises ValueError for index of "lp__"
items.body:
#### Summary:
model.py optimizing() function raises ValueError for index of "lp__"
Ran into this issue while calling FB Prophet library, which internally uses PyStan.

#### Description:
```
import pandas as pd
from fbprophet import Prophet

    df = # initialize data frame
    model = Prophet()
    model.fit(df)
    future = model.make_future_dataframe(periods=24*num_days)
    forecast = model.predict(future)
```

In model.py, depending on the data (and potentially even the OS), this will raise a ValueError since
idx_of_lp is not found.
```
        idx_of_lp = m_pars.index('lp__')
        del m_pars[idx_of_lp]
        del p_dims[idx_of_lp]
```

Error:
```
ValueError: 'lp__' is not in list
```

I was able to work around it by adding an if-check:
```
        if "lp__" in m_pars:
            del m_pars[idx_of_lp]
            del p_dims[idx_of_lp]
```

#### Reproducible Steps:
This doesn't seem very easy to reproduce since a customer reported it on RHEL 7 with fbprophet==0.2.1 (requires pandas, numpy, pystan)
pystan==2.17.1.0

I tried on my local environment and did not get a repro, but the code snippet above fixed it.

#### Current Output:
Raises a ValueError exception.


#### Expected Output:
Should provide the forecast.

#### PyStan Version:
PyStan 2.17.1.0 (doesn't seem fixed in develop branch either)

#### Python Version:
Python 2.7

#### Operating System:
RHEL 7

items.title: ImportError: DLL load failed: The specified module could not be found.
items.body:
#### Summary:
I have tried to install PyStan using my Anaconda 5.0.0 following the instructions on the PyStan on Windows documentation here: https://pystan.readthedocs.io/en/latest/windows.html#windows 


#### Description:
I did each step starting with installing the C++ compiler using `conda install libpython m2w64-toolchain -c msys2` and it made the file `distutils.cfg` in the correct directory. I then followed the dependencies steps as ` conda install numpy cython -c conda-forge` and then `conda install matplotlib scipy pandas -c conda-forge` which all seemed fine. Finally, I used the recommended `pip install pystan` and this was successful.

The problem starts when I try and verify everything was installed successfully. I open python from command prompt and type: `import pystan` and I straight away get this.

#### Current Output:
```
Python 3.6.2 |Anaconda, Inc.| (default, Sep 19 2017, 08:03:39) [MSC v.1900 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import pystan
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\Shared\Anaconda3_64\lib\site-packages\pystan\__init__.py", line 9, in <module>
    from pystan.api import stanc, stan
  File "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\Shared\Anaconda3_64\lib\site-packages\pystan\api.py", line 14, in <module>
    import pystan._api  # stanc wrapper
ImportError: DLL load failed: The specified module could not be found.
```

#### PyStan Version: 2.18.0.0

#### Python Version: 3.6

#### Operating System: Windows 10

I just wanted to install Stan to follow along with a text book that I have.

items.title: cvodes broken
items.body:
cvodes should use the current folder structure (Sundials).

I tried to fix this by following cmakelist in cvodes folder, but I couldn't get `STAN_SUNDIALS_FPRINTF` to link correctly.

https://github.com/stan-dev/math/blob/develop/lib/sundials_3.1.0/src/cvodes/CMakeLists.txt

`STAN_SUNDIALS_FPRINTF` is defined in here: https://github.com/stan-dev/math/blob/develop/lib/sundials_3.1.0/include/stan_sundials_printf_override.hpp

Based on the quick google apparently either distutils.Extension is "broken" and it might be fixed with setuptools. Other one was that the order of included libs should come after -o python_module.so

`extra_link_args` going to Extension does put stuff after the `.so` but I still couldn't get it to link.

items.title: Remove all warnings from the main library
items.body:
`pystan/model.py` has:

```
try:
            _sem = multiprocessing.Semaphore()
            del _sem  # cleanup
        except (ImportError, OSError) as e:
            multiprocessing = None
            warnings.warn('%s. _map_parallel will operate in serial mode' % (e,))
```

`warnings.warn('%s. _map_parallel will operate in serial mode' % (e,))` should use logger.

items.title: The package demands a build at install time
items.body:
#### Summary:
The Cython maintainers recommend that packages using Cython ship their pre-compiled code to avoid having to depend on building at install time that would also mutate the result.

http://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/source_files_and_compilation.html#distributing-cython-modules

#### Description:
We got stuck with installing fbprophet (as part of installing packages from a requirements.txt) without having Cython installed in advance.  The log showed that pip downloaded Cython first, then downloaded pystan and ran its setup which failed because Cython was not installed.
```
Collecting Cython>=0.22 (from fbprophet==0.3.post2->-r requirements.txt (line 11))
  Downloading https://XXXX/artifactory/api/pypi/pypi/packages/76/64/110bacbf53fe2cf545b0ede8b92d787a1244c655d483472b6ed1964716bc/Cython-0.28.5-cp37-cp37m-win32.whl (2.2MB)
    100% |....| 2.2MB 4.5MB/s
Collecting pystan>=2.14 (from fbprophet==0.3.post2->-r requirements.txt (line 11))
  Downloading https://XXXX/artifactory/api/pypi/pypi/packages/40/69/259304776a6fca45b70e1577c184c2ef6de00630be2e26cd5d5a63581fb2/pystan-2.17.1.0.tar.gz (13.9MB)
    100% |....| 13.9MB 1.1MB/s
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
      File "C:\Users\XXXX\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-install-5bk2k1e_\pystan\setup.py", line 121, in <module>
        from Cython.Build.Inline import _get_build_extension
    ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'Cython'
    ----------------------------------------
Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 1 in C:\Users\XXXX\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-install-5bk2k1e_\pystan\
```

I gather that it may still be possible to implement the build-time requirement of Cython as part of the install-time ones.  An improvement in pip 6.1.0 introduced a topological sort of the requirements

https://github.com/pypa/pip/commit/c85f1d6ff1de2b7f4110f5b936a62e4c2bfe8b28

but with regards to using Cython at install time, I still believe packages should remain packages rather than bootstrapping systems.

#### PyStan Version:
2.17.1.0

#### Python Version:
3.7 (I guess from another log)

#### Operating System:
Windows

items.title: Use of logger in setup.py
items.body:
I noticed that I added a call `logger.warning` in setup.py, but setup.py doesn't use logger. 

This does not affect our users, other than it will raise error of not knowing what is logger. Normally it would try to compile Stan library and would fail after some minutes.

So should we import logger to setup.py or use warning?

I don't really think raising an error is the correct thing to do, if future MSVC version could work with Stan libs.

items.title: Users should be able to provide mass matrix as input
items.body: I'm told this is already in CmdStan. If it's supported by RStan, it should certainly be supported by PyStan.

items.title: Build failure with Xcode 9.4.1

Not sure what is happening. Looks like clang doesn't like some of the compile flags?

See

https://travis-ci.org/stan-dev/pystan-wheels/jobs/418404995

This is holding up releasing wheels on PyPI.

items.title: StanFit4Model produces duplicate traceplot for parameter
Weird failure with conda on Windows
items.body:
Apparently the `m2w64-toolchain` + `libpython` will fail sometimes if one has tried to install pystan with pip before.

Somehow it fails to install `vs2015_runtime`. It should work after one manually installs it.

I had this problem and npt sure was it for pystan or httpstan. Either way reinstalling the whole environment did fix it at that time.

items.title: German locale breaks inference
items.body:
#### Summary:
A locale which defines decimal numbers with coma (e.g. 0,5) result in faulty cpp code. The code runs without any errors or warnings, but the inference is meaningless.

#### Description:
After running this code with
env LANG=de_DE.UTF-8

```
from pystan import StanModel

code = """
data {
      int<lower=0> N;
      vector[N] y;
}
parameters {
    real<lower=0> theta;
}
model {
    y ~ inv_gamma(0.5 * theta, 0.5 * theta);
}
"""

sm = StanModel(model_code=code)
```

and looking into `sm.model_cppcode`
one finds this line
`lp_accum__.add(inv_gamma_log<propto__>(y, (0,5.0 * theta), (0,5.0 * theta)));`

Running the same code with
env LANG=en_GB.utf8
generates this instead
`lp_accum__.add(inv_gamma_log<propto__>(y, (0.5 * theta), (0.5 * theta)));`

#### PyStan Version:
The bug occurred after upgrading from 2.17.0 to 2.17.1

#### Python Version:
Python 3.6.5

#### Operating System:
Ubuntu 16.04.4 LTS
